message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of red flag symptoms (e.g. weakness or changes in bowel/bladder function), along with normal physical examination results, suggests that the most likely cause of the patient’s lower back pain is musculoskeletal strain. Conservative treatment such as Naproxen and activity as tolerated are appropriate first-line therapies for most cases of acute low back pain. CRP level might be helpful if there is a suspicion of infection, but there is no indication of infection in this case. MRI spine is not necessary at this point and should be reserved for cases with worsening or persistent symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest non-specific lower back pain with no red flag findings. In such cases, conservative management with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and gradual return to activity is preferred. MRI spine is not immediately necessary unless red flag findings are present. CRP level is not necessary as it is not specific for back pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of neurological deficits indicates a likely mechanical cause of the back pain. The most appropriate next step in management is to start with conservative management, such as pain management with Naproxen and activity as tolerated. An MRI spine may be ordered if symptoms persist or worsen. A CRP level is not likely to be helpful in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of leg pain, weakness or change in sensation in the legs, as well as the absence of incontinence, suggests that there is unlikely to be any nerve involvement. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management would be to alleviate the back pain with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) such as Naproxen and encourage activity as tolerated. An MRI spine may be considered if the pain persists or worsens, or if there are any neurological symptoms. CRP level may not be helpful in this case as it is a nonspecific marker of inflammation. Bed rest may actually delay recovery and cause muscle deconditioning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lack of focal spine tenderness, intact sensation, and strength indicate that the lower back pain is likely not due to a serious condition. Treatment with Naproxen and activity as tolerated is appropriate initial management for uncomplicated low back pain. MRI spine would be indicated if the pain persists or worsens despite initial treatment, or if there is a change in neurological status. CRP level is not necessary for the evaluation of uncomplicated low back pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest non-specific lower back pain, which is usually self-limited, and can be treated with pain management and activity as tolerated. An MRI spine may be considered if symptoms persist, worsen, or if red flags are present. CRP level is not useful in the evaluation of non-specific lower back pain.

We refer to UpToDate articles on medicine for help. The patient's history and examination suggest an acute episode of mechanical low back pain. Imaging is not necessary for the initial management of acute low back pain. The most appropriate next step in management would be to provide pain management with NSAIDs (such as naproxen) and to encourage activity as tolerated. CRP level and MRI spine are not necessary in the initial management of acute low back pain. Bed rest may even worsen symptoms and delay recovery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s lack of neurological deficits and intact sensation make a serious underlying condition less likely. Therefore, conservative management with pain control such as Naproxen and activity as tolerated is appropriate. MRI spine and CRP level may be necessary if symptoms persist or worsen.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of mechanical low back pain, which is best managed with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and activity as tolerated. CRP levels are not informative in the management of back pain, and MRI is only indicated if there is suspicion of a more serious underlying condition. Bed rest is no longer recommended as it may prolong recovery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of neurological symptoms suggests a musculoskeletal cause of the back pain. Treatment with NSAIDs like naproxen and activity as tolerated is appropriate in this case. Other options like CRP level and MRI spine are not necessary at this time unless symptoms worsen or fail to improve with conservative management.
